title: Import Pinia Store Into Other Store
description: Learn how to access other stores within a store using Pinia.

children.value: Pinia makes state management within Vue apps a breeze to work with.
A common problem I run into is needing to access state from a different store. This can be solved using Pinia's composition syntax rather than the option syntax.
They can now be imported and used within other Pinia stores like so:

title: Nuxt 3 and Pinia
description: Integrate Pinia as your state management library for your Nuxt 3 application.

meta.name: og:description
meta.content: Integrate Pinia as your state management library for your Nuxt 3 application.

children.value: Integrate Pinia as your state management library for your Nuxt 3 application.
Evan You, the creator of Vue himself, has stated "Pinia is de facto Vuex 5! At this point it’s really a naming/branding issue."
For the time being, it's probably best to be looking towards Pinia content rather than Vuex.

props.alt: "Pinia is de facto Vuex 5! At this point it’s really a naming/branding issue."

children.value: regarding this to get a better understanding as to why Pinia > Vuex.
Pinia nearly comes with first-class support for Nuxt 3. You'll need to install two packages:
Add Pinia to your nuxt.config file
Now build a named store. For my use-case, I needed to manage state regarding filters, so the skeleton of my store looks like:
This is just showing the general structure of your store. The key is to

as my id but it could be anything you prefer.

The above example is a valid Pinia store using a pattern similar to Vue's Options API. You can also define your store using a syntax similar to the Composition API.
Here's how you can build the above example in a composable way:
We just reduced the amount of code significantly. Pretty cool, right? I personally prefer the composition.

With our store in place, simply import it into the component you want to use it in and have fun!

title: Global State Management in an Electron Application
description: Learn to utilize Pinia alongside VueJS within an Electron app to easily manage UI state.

meta.name: og:title
meta.content: Global State Management in an Electron Application

meta.name: og:description
meta.content: Learn to utilize Pinia alongside VueJS within an Electron app to easily manage UI state.

children.value: Global State Management in an Electron Application using Pinia and VueJS
into our Electron application to manage its internal state. This post assumes you have followed along with my previous
A Store is an entity that manages the global state of your application. It allows you to read and write to, regardless of the component you are working within.
You may have heard of other packages that help manage a store, Vuex is the standard for Vue and Redux is the standard for React.
This assumes you are using Vue 3.
If you are using Vue 2, please refer to their
Because we are hooking this up to an Electron application, which is just Javascript with extra steps, we can utilize our favorite package manager such as

props.code:
yarn add pinia
# or with npm
npm install pinia

children.value: function to attach it to the VueJS app:

props.code:
// renderer/main.js

import { createApp } from 'vue'
import App from './App.vue'
import { createPinia } from 'pinia'

createApp(App)
  .use(createPinia())
  .mount('#app')

children.value: Pinia is now available throughout your Electron application where Vue is available.
name. In this case, I am using
as the unique id attached to this store.
// useMainStore could be anything like useUser, useCart
// the first argument is a unique id of the store across your application
Using our store within a VueJS component
Now that our store is made, we can import it into individual components, allowing our components to interact with the store.
function, I call our store function and set the value within a const variable:
This allows me to interact with my store. For this simple example, I am displaying the message defined within the
The entire component can be seen below:

While HMR is built into Pinia, it doesn't play well with Electron and requires a bit of additional configuration.
Pinia provides additional documentation of this topic
HMR (Hot Module Replacement) allows you to edit your stores and see the changes within your app without having to reload the page or restart your server.
store looks like after updating it to allow for HMR:
in my case), it gives us HMR!
